analysis_type.name: Protester
analysis_type.instructions: The highlighted text describes an event occurring during the Occupy movement. We need your help to categorize what kind of event this was. Compare the information in the highlighted text to the definitions in the table below.

glossary.blocking action: protesters intentionally block access to transportation or commercial infrastructure. E.g. protesters block access to government buildings, streets, sidewalks, light rail systems, bank buildings, shipping ports, etc.
glossary.voluntary dissolution of a camp: protesters pack up tents and structures and leave the site of their encampment without being directly forced by police officers.
glossary.establishing a camp: protesters set up two or more tents with the intention of camping multiple nights on location.
glossary.strategic violence: protesters carry out a pre-planned act of violence against other humans eg. Kidnapping, bombing, assassination, assault. Note: only use this classification for the event if it is clear that the highlighted text describes activities that were planned in advance.
glossary.strategic sabotage: protesters carry out pre-planned act of destruction of physical property eg vandalism, setting fires, breaking windows, etc. Note: only use this classification for the event if it is clear that the highlighted text describes activities that were planned in advance.
glossary.march\/parade: protesters move along a path usually chanting and holding signs. Note: if protesters spend time at their starting point or destination listening to speeches or musicians, that should be counted as a rally (an event separate from the march/parade).
glossary.counter-protester: individual protesting against the occupy movement
glossary.rally\/demonstration: protesters stay in one spot while listening to speeches or musicians, chanting, carrying signs, etc.
glossary.strike: protesters and allies refuse to work at a specified time. Sometimes participants will carry signs and attempt to shame people who do not participate.
glossary.disrupting an on-going event of the perc: protesters disrupt an event held by people they oppose eg protesters shout down politician who is speaking, intentionally disrupt city council meeting, or interrupt the proceedings of a fundraiser, etc.
glossary.moving a camp to a new location: protesters pack up tents and structures and leave the site of their encampment and establish a camp at a new location. Note: if only some campers leave the original camp the event should be categorized as the establishment of a new camp. (NOTE: implies the dissolution of the previous camp, so only count it as a move if the other camp is dissolving in the process. if the old camp survives while some of the people move to a new location, the move to a new location should simply be coded as the establishment of a new camp.)
glossary.independent: citizen or other person not affiliated with the camp, media, police, or city
glossary.divestment action: protesters close their accounts with banks they oppose and encourage others to do so as well.

questions.text: What type of event is described in the highlighted text?

answers.text: Disrupting an on-going event of the perceived 1%
Moving a camp to a new location

questions.text: What did the crowd block?
What type of event did the protesters disrupt?
What is the title of the 1% who is being protested against?
What type of strategic violence occurred?
What type of strategic sabotage occurred?
Which of the following information does the text give about the event's location?

answers.text: An approximate location, or clues about where the event took place

questions.text: Exactly where did the event take place?
Approximately where did the event take place?
Which of the following information does the text give about the number of protesters in attendance?
Exactly how many protesters were in attendance?
Approximately how many protesters were in attendance?
Who estimated the number of protesters in attendance?

answers.text: Citizen or other person not affiliated with the camp, media, police, or city

questions.text: Which of the following information does the text give about the number of police in attendance?
Exactly how many police were in attendance?
Approximately how many police were in attendance?
Who estimated the number of police in attendance?

answers.text: Citizen or other person not affiliated with the camp, media, police, or city

questions.text: Which of the following groups and identities were in attendance?

answers.text: A wide variety of groups and identities

questions.text: Which of the following economic class groups were in attendance?
Which of the following age groups were in attendance?
Which of the following educational attainment groups were in attendance?

answers.text: College degree (B.A., B.S., trade school, technical school)
A wide variety of educational attainment levels

questions.text: Which career fields/occupations were in attendance?

answers.text: A wide variety of career fields/occupations

questions.text: Which of the following information does the text give about when the event occurred?

answers.text: The duration (the length of time the event lasted after it began)

questions.text: When exactly did the event begin?
Approximately when did the event begin?
When exactly did the event end?
Approximately when did the event end?
Approximately how long did the event last?

answers.text: More than a few hours: 3-5 hours

questions.text: Which of the following information does the text give about arrests that occurred during the event?
Exactly how many arrests occurred during the event? (if the text specifically states, "no arrests were made," then type in the number 0.)
Approximately how many arrests occurred?

answers.text: Multiple hundreds, several hundreds: 501 or more

questions.text: Who was arrested?
Which of the following information does the text give about when the arrests occurred?
Exactly when did the arrests occur?
Approximately when did the arrests occur?
Which of the following information does the text give about the number of protesters injured during the event?
Exactly how many protesters were injured during the event? (if the text specifically states, "no injuries occurred," then type the number 0.)
Approximately how many protesters were injured during the event?

answers.text: Multiple hundreds, several hundreds: 501 or more

questions.text: Which of the following information does the text give about when the protesters were injured?
Exactly when were the protesters injured?
Approximately when were the protesters injured?
Which of the following information does the text give about the number of police injured during the event?
Exactly how many police were injured during the event? (if the text specifically states, "no injuries occurred," then type in the number 0.)
Approximately how many police were injured during the event?

answers.text: Multiple hundreds, several hundreds: 501 or more

questions.text: Which of the following information does the text give about when the police were injured?
Exactly when were the police injured?
Approximately when were the police injured?
Was the event permitted?
Which of the following information does the text give about the event permits time frame?
tm Exactly when did the event permit start?
Approximately when did the event permit start?
tm Exactly when did the event permit expire?
Approximately when did the event permit expire?
Does the event permit come with conditions or requirements that the protesters must follow?
Which are conditions or requirements of the event permit?

answers.text: The crowd must not exceed a certain number of people
Must not place signage or banners
Must not sell merchandise, food, or beverage
Must not block or restrict public property
Tents and other semi-permanent structures cannot be present

questions.text: Was a permit necessary in order to hold the event, even though protesters did not acquire a permit?
Is the city government and/or police informally allowing the event, despite it not having a permit?
Which of the following parties responded to the event?

answers.text: Community group that is not Occupy (ex. church, interest group, local organization)
Passerby/onlooker, individual not affiliated with the event (ex. citizens, local business owners)

questions.text: What was the party's level of support?

article.text:
Santa Cruz city attorney sues Occupy campers for nuisance
By Stephen Baxter
Posted:   11/12/2011 01:30:34 AM PST


SANTA CRUZ -- Santa Cruz city attorneys have filed a lawsuit against Occupy Santa Cruz to cease being a public nuisance at San Lorenzo Park, where demonstrators have been camping since Oct. 8.
Judge Timothy Volkmann is expected to rule Wednesday whether the city's injunction served Thursday will be granted to cease what deputy city attorneys calls a nuisance in the park. Deputy City Attorney Caio Arellano named Occupy Santa Cruz legal team member Steve Pleich in the suit as well as 100 John Does.
Pleich, who said he does not speak for the group, said he would help argue the group's case in court.
"I'm going to be defending myself to the fullest extent of the law," Pleich said Friday. "We could abate the nuisance without leaving the park."
Deputies served a handful of citations for lodging to the camp early Friday morning.
Mayor Ryan Coonerty said Friday that the lawsuit was filed in part because park workers and park users have complained about problems in the camp.
"Most of the complaints are coming from county workers who are seeing feces, drug use and other illegal activities happening," Coonerty said. "They want us to take action."
Santa Cruz police also reported that a camper punched a county parks worker in the face Nov. 2 after the worker's leaf blower woke him early that morning. The man was arrested on suspicion of assault, Deputy Chief Steve Clark said.
On Nov. 4, city officials gave Occupy leaders a permit for the demonstration, which was not requested by the demonstrators. It ordered the activists to disband the campsite by noon Wednesday and clarified other rules of the park that addressed trash, toilets and other issues.
Dozens of the city's homeless have been drawn to the park not necessarily as a political statement but because they are often not ticketed for lodging or illegal camping, authorities said.
"What I hear from most residents is that they overwhelmingly support the Occupy cause -- as does the City Council -- but we're just worried about the health and safety impacts on the park. Every other group in Santa Cruz who holds an event like this has a permit and has conditions, so we're just asking the same from this group," Coonerty said.
The Occupy Santa Cruz group formed as an echo of the Occupy Wall Street protest in New York that opposes national bank bailouts and economic disparities countrywide.
Coonerty said City Council members discussed the lawsuit this week.
Vice Mayor Don Lane and other city officials have discussed the camping problems with Occupy leaders several times to try to iron out an agreement for the camp to end when the permit ends on Wednesday.
Coonerty said city leaders are trying to avoid a "showdown" with Occupy campers and a forced withdrawal.
One rule in the permit required the demonstrators to provide three portable restrooms in parking spots on Ocean Street. There is one portable restroom there now, Pleich said.
The leaderless Occupy Santa Cruz "general assembly" has not yet decided whether to add more toilets, he said.
